bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to James Carroll, September 24, 1900

div1.p: Reed discusses the mosquito as the vector for yellow fever and the amount of evidence necessary to prove this hypothesis.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to James Carroll, September 24, 1900
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Sept. 24, '00
Dear Carroll;
div1.p:
Your letter
of Septr 20th has just
been received, telling
me of Lazear's attack-
I am now anxiously
awaiting Maj. Kean's
next cable. Dear Me!
I think that I have ex-
perienced more men-
tal distress during this
month of September than
ever before & I had
hoped to be happiest
during this time-
Although Kean's Cable
of yesterday said, “Severe
Case - much albumen-
high temperature”, I
can but believe that
Lazear will pull through.
I hope & pray that
he does come out
alright.

Now, concerning the
mosquito propagation
of the parasite, I am
intensely interested,
but I cannot say that
any of your cases, except,
perhaps Dean's, prove
anything- If you, my dear
Doctor, had prior to
your bite, remained
at Camp Columbia
for 10 days, then we
would have had a
clear case, but you
didn't! You went just
where you might have
contracted the disease from
another source - and un-
fortunately Lazear was
bitten at Las Animas
Hospital! That knocks
his case out! I mean
for as a thoroughly scien-
tific experiment, that
would bear strictest
scrutiny. If Dean did
not leave the HospitalPost
after leaving the Hospital
his case is satisfactory,
& proves a great deal.
If his case will with-
stand criticism, then
your & Lazear's cases would
be confirmatory- Understand
that I firmly believe in
the Mosquito theory & that
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
the Mosquito is a very
Common Culex found
all along our sea-
board. I am only
regretting that 2 such
valuables lives have
been put in jeopardy,
under circumstances
in which the results
obtained would not
be above Criticism.
Hoping to be with
you soon, sincerely.
div1.closer:
Your friend, Reed. Love to
Lazear --
